t: Job 16
Jobâ€™s Reply to Eliphaz
Then*p Job answered:
I*pn have heard many things like these. You*ln are all miserable comforters.
Is*ln there no end to your empty words? What*ln provokes you that you continue testifying?
If*ln you were in my place I could also talk like you. I*ln could string words together against you and*ln shake my head at you.
Instead,*ln I would encourage you with my mouth, and*ln the consolation from my lips would bring relief.
If*pn I speak, my suffering is not relieved, and*ln if I hold back, does any of it leave me?
Surely*ln he has now exhausted me. You*ln have devastated my entire family.
You*ln have shriveled me up- it has become a witness; my*ln frailty rises up against me and testifies to my face.
His*ln anger tears at me, and he harasses me. He*ln gnashes his teeth at me. My*ln enemy pierces me with his eyes.
They*ln open their mouths against me and*ln strike my cheeks with contempt; they*ln join themselves together against me.
God*ln hands me over to the unjust; he*ln throws me to the wicked.
I*ln was at ease, but he shattered me; he*ln seized me by the scruff of the neck and*ln smashed me to pieces. He*ln set me up as his target;
his*ln archers surround me. He*ln pierces my kidneys without mercy and*ln pours my bile on the ground.
He*ln breaks through my defenses again and again; he*ln charges at me like a warrior.
I*pn have sewn sackcloth over my skin; I*ln have buried my strength in the dust.
My*ln face has grown red with weeping, and*ln darkness covers my eyes,
although*ln my hands are free from violence and*ln my prayer is pure.
Earth,*pn do not cover my blood; may*ln my cry for help find no resting place.
Even*ln now my witness is in heaven, and*ln my advocate is in the heights!
My*ln friends scoff at me as*ln I weep before God.
I*ln wish that someone might argue for a man with God just*ln as anyone would for a friend.
For*ln only a few years will pass before*ln I go the way of no return.
